pages.text: $(o)Ah! While I expected to be right, I wasn't anticipating how-- well, dramatic it could get. It seems that in lieu of $(thing)Base Powers$(0) to consume, the Corrupt Cell begins breaking down the wards of the Crucible themselves.

$(o)The degradation does not occur while the Corrupt Cell has Base Powers to eat. $(br2)Further, I have observed that if the Cell is destroyed -- or at least moved out from under the Crucible -- the wards quickly recover.

$(o)Clearly, the failure comes in stages. Runes from the Crucible's enchantment appear in the air, then a humming sound commences, and finally it fully breaks.$(br2)I do wonder what other aspects of the Crucible's functionality fail as the sequence progresses. If any of its features produce a clear $(4)signal$(0), that signal would likely turn off, allowing an automatic system to prevent the failure.
